dictionary.
IN TWO VOLUMES.
W. H. MED HURST, SEN.

SHANGHAE:
PRINTED AT THE MISSION PRESS.
1847.




PREFACE.
The basis of the following Dictionary, as well as of
the Chinese and English part, published by the same
author, is the Imperial Dictionary of Kang-he ; the
words and phrases in that Ihesaurus, after having been
rendered into English, have been arranged alphabeti-
cally, and constitute the ground-work of the volumes
now offered to the public. Of course, then, the main
part of the expressions here adduced, if the author has
not misunderstood the original, are veritably and es-
sentially Chinese, so that the student may depend, in
the majority of instances, upon getting genuine native
terms for any given English expression. In cases,
however, where the Chinese had no term, or one was
not to be found, corresponding to the requisite Englibh
word, the author has been obliged to invent phrases ；
but these are few in comparison with the mass here
brought together. It will be seen, also, on reference
to the work, that in various instances, a large num-
ber of words are accumulated, as settiiig forth the
raeaning l of individual English terms ; where the En-
glish term has possessed various shades of meaning,
these have been marked in the arrangement of the cor-
responding Chinese phrases, but sometimes under one
and the same definite English term, ten or more Chi-
nese expressions are adduced ; in these cases we
ascribe the quantity to the richness of tbe ( hinese
language, in certain particulars, or to the inability of
the cumpikr (fVom want of time and skill) to discover
the slight shades of meaning that exist among them.


Same of these terms are obsolete, and some poetical,
while a variety of others are only used by quaint and
rare authors ; and yet it was thought advisable to bring
together the majority of those adduced by the Chinese
themselves, for the benefit of more proficient students,
who mighi wish to have a choice of words in which to
clothe their ideas, or who might have to write in the
poetical or antique style.
The multitude of terms brought together, may, how-
ever, be liable to an objection from some, that they
cannot tell which to select from among the mass ; for
their benefit, therefore, the most common and obvious
terms are placed first, which will be always understood,
■while the rarer epithets follow after. .
In the phrases that are to be met with under their
respective heads, the student will see how to apply
the terms adduced, while he may rest assured that
the phrases themselves are for the most part extracted
from native sources. The Chinese being emphatically
a language of phrases, it is of importance to show the
collocation in which certain terms occur; for this pur-
pose very short extracts have been generally selected,
in order to compress the Dictionary into as small a
compass as possil)le, and at the same time to point out
what words are usually found in conjunction.
Besides the native works used in the compilation of
the following Dictionary, the author has extracted all
that he thought serviceable from Morrison, and a Latin
and Chinese Manuscript Dictionary, drawn up by some
unknown individual ； while he flatters himself that he
has gone far beyond either of his predecessors, in the
amount of foreign words adduced, and of expressions
brought together to elucidate them. On looking over
the Dictionary, some persons may be induced to ques-
tion whether all the terms given have really the mean-
ings which are asigned to them, but on referring to the
Imperial Dictionary, as well as to the Chinese and En-
glish Dictionaries already published, it will be found
that each term is capable of being established by good
authority, and therefore to be relied on.


In the execution of the present work, the author has
been able to produce a clearer page, than when pub-
lishing his Chinese ami English Dictionary, as, being
resident in one of the cities of China, he has succeeded
in getting types cut on blank bodies, prepared for the
purpose, and has thus carried the work through by
means of the letter-press. In doing this，about 15,000
sorts, and nearly 100,000 individual types, have been
required, all of which had to be cut for the purpose,
which has occasioned great expense, and some delay ;
but he trusts that the work wii】 be found to be of such
utility, as by the sale to reimburse the outlay, and though
it may not contain every thing, which a student of the
language could desire, he hopes that it will pave the
way for future efforts, which will be more successful
and more useful.
W, H. Medhurst.
Sbanghae, Feb. 3rd, 1847.


ORTHOGRAPHY.
In the orthography of the following work, as well as in the Chinese
and English Dictionary, by the same author, the mode of spelling
adopted by Dr. Morrison has been followed. According to that system,
the a, when stan ling alone or preceded by one or more consonants*
as chwa, kwa, la, rna y &c. is always pronounced long, as
in the same sound is attached to it when preceded by a vow-
el, kea, which words are to be pronounced as if consisting of
two syllables, like or rapidh 7 enunciated in one ; when the
ais followed by n, or ng, as in chan, fan, fang, &c. it has
a shorter sound, as in or ' When the a is followed
by a \owel, it retains the long sound, as chae, hae, &c. which are
pronounced like a perfect diphthong, the a being sonnded as in far,
and the eas in me. So also when ais followed by a diphthong, as
and the ou, in hound. When the a is followed by the letter
as tf/ 奶 ?/，.?•"•?/，and it possesses the slender sound ot the
English a, as. in spade, lade 9 When the ais marked short, and
is tound at the end of a word, as cha y ld, 7na, nd, kc. it is pro-
nounced very short, as in u with the pronunciation stopped,
after the enunciation ofthey«. When the short d is followed by an
t?, or wy, as in
&c. it is pronounced short, like the u in The final e, when
standing alone, or when preceded by h, Jc, I, m, n y p, s y ts, and w y
takes tlie usuAl sound i 衫 in but when preceded hy s
sz 9 and it has a peculiar sound giren to it, something similar
to the in or rather as if the vowel were suppressed entirely,
and only that of the consonants heard ; on -which account some writers
in giving the sounds of these words, have omitted the vow-
el altogether, and written ch\ sh\ sz\ and tsz\ The sound of be-
fore a vowel is long, as in while each of the vowels should be e-
nunciated distinctly, as if the words consisted of two or three syllables
rapidly combined into one ; thus shouli be pronounced
ke-a-e, kc. so also when ay, aou, en, un,
w y the sound should be as if written, ke-ay,
The short e final as ia je and has a contracted sound, like
the e in u supposing the voice to be suddenly stopped, at me.
This sound of the e is frequently met with when preceded by another
from which it is to be separated as if by a hyphen, thus hee kee 9
lee y mee y nee, pee, tee, tsee, should he pronounced as if written
he-e, ke-Gy rne~e y &c. The diphthong e'i occurs in heth y keih y
lezh, meih, &c. in which cases the sound of the e is scarcely dis-
tinguishable from the z, and to be pronounced as the ei in
with the I suddenly checked in the utterance. The e followed by w
is to be pronounced like the French u. The i followed by ?/, and
as in chin, chin ff, hin, jin,jin g, kin, kivg, lin, ling y
kc. is pronounced short ; as in the words and
; but when i is followed by h it represents various sounds, ac-


cording to the consonants by which it is preceded ; thui, when ch，
and are prefixed, the iis sounded short, as in with
the latter part of the word suddenly suppressed ; when the i followed
by h, is preceded by k and /, it is pronounced like short uin
as if the voice were suddenly checked at cu ; and when i followed by
h, is preceded by m, /?, s y i, and ts, it has the sound of short e r in
with the final t stopped short. It could have been wished
that Dr. Morrison had chosen different vowels, for expressing these
varying sounds, but havmg once adopted the short t for all, and Eng-
lish students of Chinese having generally fallen into the habit of using
the short z only, it was not thought worth while, in this Dictionary,
to disturb the common usage. The explanations above given, will,
however, tend to remove much of the obscurity that has hitherto hung
over the pronunciation of the juh sound in Chinese. The final
〇 when preceded by Jc, l,m,n y 5, t 9 ts， and w, has the long
sound of the o in but the short final 6 ha? a peculiar sound, ac-
cording to the position in which it stands; when used alone, or pre-
ceded by the consonants /, m, n,p t s, &c. it has the short
sound of o in as if the pronunciation were suddenly stopped,
before the enunciation of the final consonant; but when preceded by
A, ， 々， it has rather a lengthened sound, as if divided into two syl-
lables, and written ko-ut 9 rapidly conjoined into one, with the
final consonant checked. The letter u when followed by n 9 and ng y
as in chung y &c., has the sound of u in when followed
by y % as in chuy^juy y luy, suy, shuy, iuy y and isuy y it is to
be pronounced as if divided into two syllables, viz. chu-wy, ju-wy,
of the u 9 when followed by en y as in
tseun 9 and yuen, as if the words had been written he-yo~un 9
peculiar sound is found in hwan, lew an hvan, mwan, nwan，
pwan, swan, twan 9 tswan 9 and wan, as if the same were written
ho-Tvatiy Jco-wan, 10-wan,mo-wan y no~wan, &c. pronounced in one.
It is believed that the above remarks, if attended to, will be sufficient
to guide the learner, in pronouncing the vowel sounds used in Dr.
orthography. With regard to the consonants little need be
said, as they are generally conformed to the sounds of the English
letters, except which is like the French^*; and the r, in urh,
which is a sound between an r and an I, and not to be pronounced so
harehly as the English r. The g in every instance is hard, as in u jet. i9

Accent, dialect, or brogue,
土音 t’hob h
heang tan, the
tones of the Chinese language,
聲音 shing yin ; stress laid
on particular k講
話輕重k%ngk，hiug
cfidng; the marks put upon
characters to regulate their pro
mmciation， 圍圏 we i k，heu“
To accentuate, to place
the proper accent over words,
文字圍圈 w5n tsz6 wei
k lieueii j the Chinese form
the accent over a character by
a small circle, 〇 ; which they
call a _ k'hcuen, or nagj


and place it on different parts of
the character, to distinguish the
accent, and to point out whe-
ther the word in question is to
be used as a substantive or a
verb; thus wang, a king,
with the addition of such a
mark on the right side at the
top，becomes wang, to
reign; chung, heavy, with
such a mark on the left side, at
the bottom, c 重 chung,
to repeat; too, a measure,
with the same mark on the
right side, at the bottom, de-
notes to, to measure; &
ch s ho〇, a place, with the above
diacritical mark on the left
side at the lop, is turned into
ch’hob, to place; the marks
so arranged form the four tones
of the Chinese language, known
severally as the ping, even,
It shang, upper, de-
parting, and juh, entering
tones.
